Institute of Catalysis for Energy and Environment, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shenyang Normal University Shenyang 110034 China The development of stable Pt-based catalysts is important for propane dehydrogenation process. In this work, Mn-SBA-15 supports with different Mn doping amounts were prepared by in situ hydrothermal method using citric acid and urea. Compared with Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, the significantly improved dispersion and stability of Pt on Pt/Mn-SBA-15 catalysts were demonstrated by X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy results. CO DRIFT spectra analysis showed the electron transfer from Mn to Pt occurred, which led to an increase in the electron density of Pt. And the propane dehydrogenation performances over Pt/Mn-SBA-15 were enhanced significantly. Among them, the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 shows the highest initial propane conversion of 51.2% and lowest deactivation rate constant of 0.013 h−1. The reason may be that appropriate amount of Mn can modify Pt by both electronic effect and geometric effect. And the strong metal-support interaction formed by highly dispersed MnO x anchor sites in Mn-SBA-15 support maintains the stability of Pt during the propane dehydrogenation reaction. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Propane dehydrogenation Support anchoring effect Stable Pt-based Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is a basic raw material used in the production of polypropylene, acrylonitrile, acrolein, acetone, and other industrial products.[1–3] The traditional methods of obtaining propylene are the catalytic cracking of oil and the cracking of naphtha, which makes it unable to meet current demand.[4] Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) to propylene as an on-purpose propylene production route provides an alternative approach and has attracted extensive attention.[5,6]. Platinum-based catalysts are widely used in PDH reactions because of their superior propane C–H bond activation.[7,8] Most Pt-based catalysts operate at above 500 °C to attain high propane conversion. However, such harsh reaction conditions in PDH reactions cause catalyst deactivation due to Pt sintering and coke deposition.[9] The modification of Pt with a second metal is an efficient strategy to enhance the stability of these catalysts.[10] Promoters, such as Sn, [11–15] Ga, [16–18] In, [19–21] Zn, [22,23] and Cu[24,25] can enhance the catalytic performance of Pt-based catalysts by improving the geometric dispersion of Pt and modifying its electric structure. Recently, Mn was reported to act as a promoter that can considerably enhance the PDH performance of Pt-based catalysts.[26,27] Our previous work had found that a highly dispersed MnO x decorated dendritic mesoporous silica nanoparticle (DMSN) support shows exceptionally ability to disperse and stabilize Pt clusters. The alloying of Pt and Mn allows electron transfer from Mn to Pt to occur, which leads to an increase in the electron density of Pt and enhances propene desorption.[28] Compared with a DMSN support, SBA-15 shows a highly ordered mesoporous structure.[29] Most importantly, it is prepared in acidic conditions, which avoids the direct precipitation of Mn precursors as MnO x agglomerates or crystals under alkaline conditions during the synthesis of DMSN. That is, acidic conditions are conducive to the formation of highly dispersed MnO x anchor sites. However, the rapid hydrolysis of the silica precursor in strongly acidic conditions makes the rapid formation of monolith SBA-15 and Mn precursor the dominant species in the solution because of the large difference in condensation speed between the silica and Mn precursors. A weakly acidic system, in which the hydrolysis of silica precursor is slow [30], is beneﬁcial for in situ functional modification. Herein, the Mn-SBA-15 supports were prepared under weakly acidic conditions using citric acid and urea to balance the condensation speed of silica and Mn precursors to promote the formation of highly dispersed MnO x anchor sites. In order to investigate the optimal interaction between the active component Pt and Mn-SBA-15 support, different contents of transition metal Mn species were included as additives during the preparation of SBA-15, and a synergistic effect between Pt active sites and the support in PDH performance of the catalysts were explored. The PDH performance over Pt/SBA-15 can be significantly enhanced by introducing Mn. The addition of Mn with an appropriate amount in SBA-15 supports enhances the interaction of metal Pt and support, resulting in high dispersion and stability of Pt on Pt/Mn-SAB-15 catalysts, which results in improved PDH performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of Mn-SBA-15 The Mn-SBA-15 support was synthesized using an in situ hydrothermal method. In a typical procedure, 3 g of P123 was added to 112 mL of deionized water and stirred until the P123 was completely dissolved. Then 6.9 g of citric acid, 3.6 g of urea, Mn(NO3)2, and 13.4 mL of tetraethyl orthosilicate were added and stirred for 24 h. The mixture was transferred to a stainless steel Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 100 °C for 24 h, and then the autoclave was cooled. The samples were filtered, washed, and dried at 60 °C for 24 h. Finally, the Mn-SBA-15 support was obtained by calcining at 550 °C for 6 h. The theoretical doping of the transition metal Mn doping amounts are 5 wt%, 10 wt%, and 20 wt%. For clarity, the Mn-SBA-15 supports are named xMn-SBA-15, where x represents the Mn doping amount. The preparation of the SBA-15 support was performed using the procedure as that for Mn-SBA-15 except for the absence of Mn(NO3)2. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Pt/xMn-SBA-15 Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts were prepared using the incipient wetness impregnation method with H2PtCl6·6 H2O as the precursor. An aqueous solution of H2PtCl6·6 H2O was added to the Mn-SBA-15 support. Then, the mixture was ultrasonic treatment for 30 min and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. After which, the samples were calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. For comparison, Pt/SBA-15 was also prepared using the SBA-15 support. The Pt loading amount was 0.5 wt% on all samples. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD characterization was performed using a type UltimaⅣ diffractometer from RIGAKU. The small angle test range was 0.6–5° at a speed of 1 min−1. The wide angle test range was 10°− 90°, and the scan speed was 5° min−1. N2-adsorption/desorption was performed on a Model 3020 physical adsorption instrument. The real Mn content of the samples was tested on an AGILENT 7900 inductively coupled plasma (ICP) mass spectrometer. Raman spectroscopy was conducted using a LabRAM HR Evolution Raman spectrometer. The fresh catalysts were tested using a 325 nm laser with a range of 400–1200 cm−1, and the spent samples were tested using a 532 nm laser with a range of 1000–1800 cm−1. The zeta potential of the Mn-SBA-15 supports was tested on a Malvern Nano ZS90 analyzer. A total of 10 mg of sample was added to 1000 mL of aqueous solution, sonicated for 15 min, and the sample was transferred to the test pool for further testing. The spent catalysts were analyzed using a STA449F5 thermoweight analyzer. CO-DRIFT spectra were carried out on a Bruker VERTEX 80 v Fourier-transformed infrared spectrometer with an MCT detector. The samples were pretreated by 10% H2/Ar at 300 °C. After switching to Ar flow and cooled to 60 °C, the samples were exposed to 10% CO/Ar for 30 min. Finally, the samples were purged with Ar and the spectra were recorded. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The activity measurements for PDH were conducted in a conventional quartz tubular microreactor. A total of 200 mg of catalyst was placed into the quartz reactor and reduced at 500 °C in 10% H2/Ar for 4 h before the reaction. A mixture of propane and N2 with a C3H8:N2 ratio of 1:2 (total 12 mL·min−1) were introduced for activity evaluation at the temperature of 590 °C. The reaction products were analyzed using an online Agilent 7890B gas chromatography. The conversion of propane, selectivity for propene, and deactivation rate constant were defined as follows: X C 3 H 8 = C H 4 + 2 C 2 H 4 + 2 C 2 H 6 + 3 C 3 H 6 C H 4 + 2 C 2 H 4 + 2 C 2 H 6 + 3 C 3 H 6 + 3 C 3 H 8 × 100 % S C 3 H 6 = 3 C 3 H 6 C H 4 + 2 C 2 H 4 + 2 C 2 H 6 + 3 C 3 H 6 × 100 % k d = ln 1 − X f i n a l X f i n a l − ln 1 − X i n i t i a l X i n i t i a l t where Xinitial and Xfinal represent the initial and final propane conversion, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterization of Mn-SBA-15 support In order to attain the real content of Mn on the Mn-SBA-15 supports, ICP characterization was conducted, and the results are shown in Table 1. Theoretically, the Mn doping amount in the support is 5 wt%, 10 wt%, and 20 wt%, respectively. From Table 1, the actual metal loads were much lower than the theoretical loadings, which implies that Mn species can only be partially doped into the surface or framework of SBA-15 support during the hydrothermal process.[31] This may be caused by the acidic conditions making the Mn precursor the dominant species in the solution. Moreover, the real Mn doping amount increases with an increase in the theoretical Mn doping amount, indicating the doping effect can be enhanced upon increasing the amount of Mn(NO3)2 in material preparation. Fig. 1 shows the zeta potential of xMn-SBA-15 supports. As shown in Fig. 1, all xMn-SBA-15 supports have negative charges in aqueous solution due to the presence of silanol groups on the surface of the SBA-15 support. With an increase in Mn doping amount, the zeta potential of the supports showed a trend of first increasing and then decreasing, with the highest potential obtained with the 10Mn-SBA-15 support. This may be caused by the formation of Si–O–Mn, which consumes a part of the silanol group, and decreases the amount of negative charge on the surface of the SBA-15 support. The zeta potential drops once more on 20Mn-SBA-15 support. This may be due to the aggregation of MnOx species on the high Mn loading sample. The aggregated MnOx species reduced the consumption of surface silanol groups of SBA-15, which results in the drops of the zeta potential. It has been found that there were mostly hydroxyl groups on the surface of the silica nanoparticles that had the highest absolute value of zeta potential among the supports. In contrast to the SBA-15 support, the modification of Mn2+ consumed the surface silanol groups of SBA-15; thus, the xMn-SBA-15 supports have fewer negative charges. During the impregnation process, the negatively charged SBA-15 support exhibited repulsion of the [PtCl6]2− species. However, the relative positive sites caused by Mn decoration can anchor [PtCl6]2− species, making it more suitable for the formation of Pt active centers with high stability and dispersion, which is more conducive to the dispersion of platinum particles. 3.2 Characterization of Pt/Mn-SBA-15 catalysts Fig. 2 shows small-angle XRD patterns of the Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts. All Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts show characteristic peaks belonging to (100), (110), and (200) planes of the hexagonal lattice of SBA-15 between 2θ angles of 0.5° and 2°[32], indicating that all Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts had an ordered mesoporous structure. The intensity of the diffraction peaks decreases with an increase in Mn doping amount, indicating that the addition of Mn reduces the degree of mesoporous order in SBA-15. It may be because Mn species enter into the SiO2 framework, influencing the cooperative assembly of the silica precursor to the ordered mesoporous structure. When the doping amount is raised to 20%, the diffraction peak shifts to a high degree, indicating a decrease in mesopore size. This may be caused by the formation of MnOx species on the surface of mesopores. Fig. 3A displays the wide-angle XRD patterns of calcined Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts and 10Mn-SBA-15 support. All samples show a characteristic diffraction peak attributed to amorphous SiO2 at 2θ of 23.5°. There is no diffraction peak ascribed to MnOx on the sample of the 10Mn-SBA-15 support, indicating the high dispersion of Mn species. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ of 39.8° and 46.2° attributed to Pt(111) and Pt(200) appeared on the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, indicating the formation of Pt particles.[34] After Mn doping, the Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalyst has a characteristic peak attributed to Pt(111) at 2θ of 39.8°, with the diffraction peak intensity lower than that of the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst. It indicates that the addition of Mn is beneficial to improve the dispersion of Pt. With an increase in Mn doping amount, no diffraction peak is ascribed to Pt in the patterns, indicating that Pt exists in a highly dispersed form on the support. In addition, there is no characteristic diffraction peak of the MnOx species, which may be because the Mn species replaced silicon atoms in the SBA-15 support, was doped into the framework of SBA-15, or formed an amorphous phase below the detection limit. The XRD results show that Mn doping does not destroy the original ordered mesoporous structure of the SBA-15 support, and the appropriate Mn doping amount is beneficial to improve the dispersion of Pt, which is favorable for improving the PDH performance of the catalyst. Fig. 3B shows the XRD patterns of the reduced Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. 3B that the reduced Pt/SBA-15 and Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalysts show characteristic peaks attributed to Pt(111) and Pt(200), and the diffraction peak intensity of the Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalyst is lower than that of the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, which shows that the addition of Mn is beneficial to improving the dispersion of Pt. The reduced Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 catalyst showed a characteristic peak attributed to PtMn3(111) at a 2θ angle of 40.7°[35], indicating the formation of PtMn3 alloy. For Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalysts, the characteristic peaks attributed to PtxMny were not detected, which may be due to the formation of highly dispersed active sites on the catalysts. Fig. 4 shows the N2-adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts with different Mn doping amounts. As shown in Fig. 4 A, Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts show type Ⅳ isotherms with an H1 hysteresis loop, indicating typical mesoporous structural characteristics.[33] The hysteresis loop of the catalyst moves to the relatively low pressure for the Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 catalyst, which indicates that the pore size of the sample decreases. It can be seen from Fig. 4B that the pore size distribution of the Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalyst is uniform, and the pore size of the catalyst gradually decreases with an increase in Mn doping amount, especially on the Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 catalyst. This is consistent with the SAXRD results. Table 2 lists the textural properties of the Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts. Among them, the specific surface areas of the Pt/SBA-15 and Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalysts are 428.5 m2·g−1 and 397.9 m2·g−1, respectively. The specific surface areas are relatively small because Pt is agglomerated in the mesopores, confirmed by the characterization results from the wide-angle XRD analysis. For the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 and Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 catalysts, the specific surface areas are 486.4 m2·g−1 and 478.6 m2·g−1, higher than those of Pt/SBA-15 and Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalysts. This may be caused by the influence of Mn(NO3)2 content on the cooperative assembly of Mn and Si precursor during the preparation of Mn-SBA-15 and the high dispersion of Pt and Mn species. The pore size and pore volume of the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst are 7.3 nm and 0.93 cm3·g−1, respectively, and those of the Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalyst are 7.1 nm and 0.86 cm3·g−1, respectively. When the Mn doping amount increases to 10%, the pore size of the catalyst decreases from 7.1 nm to 6.1 nm. When the Mn doping amount reaches 20%, the pore size of the catalyst continues to decrease to 4.7 nm, and the pore volume decreases to 0.72 cm3·g−1. This is because, with the increasing Mn content, the surface of the support is gradually covered with MnOx species, resulting in smaller pore sizes and lower pore volumes. Fig. 5 shows the Raman spectra of calcined and reduced Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts. All spectra of the calcined Pt/xMn-SBA-15 show a band at about 489 cm−1 from D1 defect modes related to the tri-cycloxiloxane ring of the SBA-15 support.[36] The calcined Pt/SBA-15 sample gives rise to a band at 982 cm−1 ascribed to the surface Si-OH stretching mode. [36] This band shifts to 978 cm−1 in the Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts, indicating the formation of the Si−O−Mn bond. [37] Moreover, the band at 582 cm−1 of the Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 sample represents the Si−O−Mn vibration.[38] This phenomenon indicates that Mn is highly dispersed on the surface of the support or enters into the framework of SBA-15. This is consistent with the characterization results from wide-angle XRD characterization. Fig. 5B displays the Raman spectra of the reduced Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. 5B that the disappearance of the peak shift at 980 cm−1 for Pt/Mn-SBA-15 and Pt/SBA-15, indicating the consumption of Mn species on the surface Si−O−Mn and the formation of PtxMny alloy. In order to investigate the morphology of the catalysts and the dispersion of Pt, the TEM, STEM images and EDS mapping are shown in Fig. 6. The highly ordered mesoporous structure is shown in all samples, indicating the formation of SBA-15 and Mn-SBA-15 support. The similar morphologies of the SBA-15 and Mn-SBA-15 supports illustrate the negligible effect on the mesoporous structure caused by in situ Mn doping during the synthesis of these supports. Moreover, the Pt nanoparticles with a size of about 10.2 nm are distributed on the Pt/SBA-15 samples, as shown in Fig. 6A. A more uniformly distributed nanoparticles are shown over Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalyst in Fig. 6B. And the size of Pt nanoparticles decreases to about 7.6 nm over Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalysts, indicating the addition of Mn increase the dispersion of Pt. With the increasing of Mn content, the nanoparticle sizes further decrease with the size of 2.2 nm and 1.5 nm on Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 and Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 catalyst, as shown in the inset of Figs. 6D and 6H. The metal dispersion is obviously improved because of the formation of highly dispersed MnOx anchor sites on the surface of Mn-SBA-15 support. Fig. 6F shows the EDS mapping and the linear scanning of a nanoparticle of Pt/10Mn-SBA-15catalyst. It can be seen that the dispersion of Mn mainly in the outside of the nanoparticle and the support, indicating the anchor effect of Mn to Pt. According to the TEM results, the addition of Mn improves the dispersion of Pt and makes it stable because of strong metal-support interaction caused by the MnOx anchor sites. In situ, DRIFT spectra of CO adsorption were performed to identify the influence of Mn on the surface structure and electronic properties of Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts, the results of which are displayed in Fig. 7. For the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, the absorption band appearing at 2071 cm−1 is ascribed to linear CO adsorbed on terrace sites of the Pt species.[39] Based on the DRIFT spectra of the Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 and Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalysts, there are two bands centered at 2058 cm−1 and 2062 cm−1 which occur upon the introduction of Mn, which are attributed to linear CO adsorbed on step sites. [40] The red shift of the CO stretching frequency and the change in adsorption position from the Pt/SBA-15 to Pt/Mn-SBA-15 catalysts indicates the formation of the PtMn alloy phase and electron transfer from Mn to Pt. [17,41] However, with a further increase in Mn doping, it is obvious that the intensity of the adsorption band decreased on the Pt/20MnSBA-15 catalyst, indicating that excessive Mn doping will lead to some active site Pt becoming covered, which will affect the activity of these Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts. 3.3 Catalytic activity measurements The performances of Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts doped with different transition metal Mn contents were evaluated for PDH reaction. Moreover, the activity of 10Mn-SBA-15 support and Pt/SBA-15 were also evaluated. Fig. 8 shows the PDH performance of the 10Mn-SBA-15 support and Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. 8 and Table 3 that the 10Mn-SBA-15 support is inactive in PDH, with an initial propane conversion and propylene selectivity of 3.6% and 52.9%, respectively. This indicates that the Mn species in the xMn-SBA-15 support has no catalytic dehydrogenation ability. For the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, the initial propane conversion is 42.6%, which indicates that Pt acted as the active site to activate the propane C–H bond. The propane conversion dropped rapidly to 15.7% after 6 h of reaction over the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, indicating rapid deactivation. When the transition metal Mn species is added, the PDH performance of these catalysts is improved. The initial propane conversion first increased and then decreased with an increase in the Mn content. The highest propane conversion is 51.2% over Pt/10Mn-SBA-15. More importantly, the deactivation is suppressed after the addition of the Mn species, which can be demonstrated by the lower deactivation rate constant, as shown in Fig. 6C. Based on Fig. 8B, displaying the change in propylene selectivity with time, it can be observed that the propylene selectivity of Pt/xMn-SBA-15, including the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, is above 97%. It indicates these catalysts produce fewer by-products, and SBA-15 is a suitable support for the PDH reaction. In summary, the PDH performance over Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts first increased and then decreased, among which the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalyst shows the highest propane conversion and the lowest deactivation rate constant of 0.013 h−1. The TOF were calculated over these catalysts and shown in Table 3. It can been seen that the TOF decrease with the increasing of Mn content. It is because of the electron transfer from Mn to Pt makes the increasing of Pt electron density and resulting in favorable desorption of propene and decreased C-H activation of propane. Moreover, because of the geometric effect of Mn, the dispersion of Pt increases with the increasing of Mn content. Therefore, although the TOF decreases, the space time yield of propene (STY) increasing with the increasing of Mn content. Upon analyzing and comparing the catalytic performance of Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalyst for PDH, it was found that with an increase in Mn doping amount, the PDH activity of these catalysts first increased and then decreased. This is due to the addition of Mn increasing the interaction between metal Pt and SBA-15 support, resulting in improved Pt dispersion. The low Mn doping amount for Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 is insufficient to anchor Pt with a certain agglomeration phenomenon of Pt occurring on the surface of SBA-15 support. Excessive Mn doping on Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 may result in the covering of Pt and a reduction in catalytic performance. With an appropriate amount of Mnn+ species in the support over Pt/10Mn-SBA-15, synergy with the SBA-15 support can be enhanced. A strong interaction between Pt and Mn formed and the electron transfer from Mn to Pt occurred, which led to an increase in the electron density of Pt and resulted in enhanced PDH performance. 3.4 Analysis of catalyst structure and carbon deposition In order to investigate the structural change in Pt/xMn-SBA-15 during the PDH reaction, XRD patterns over Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts before and after the reaction are shown in Fig. 9. The increased intensity of characteristic peaks ascribed to Pt over spent Pt/SBA-15 catalyst indicates the aggregation of Pt during the PDH reaction, which results in decreased propane conversion and rapid deactivation during the reaction. This also occurs on the Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalyst to a reduced extent. For the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalyst, there are no diffraction peaks after the reaction, indicating that the highly dispersed Pt or PtMn species possess high stability under harsh reaction conditions. The high stability of these PtMn sites contributed to the enhanced catalytic stability. Raman spectroscopy was used to characterize the coke deposition of the spent catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10, the bands at 1330 cm−1 and 1600 cm−1 in all samples belonging to the D and G bands[42]. This shows that Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts have a similar type of carbon deposition. Among them, the characteristic peak at 1330 cm−1 indicates that the generated carbon deposit exists in a disordered state[43]. The characteristic peak at 1600 cm−1 indicates carbon species with a high order in the catalyst[44]. In addition, the ratio of D-band to G-band (ID/IG) can indicate the graphitization degree of the coke.[45] The results of the ID/IG ratio are listed in Table 3. The Pt/SBA-15 and Pt/5Mn-SBA-15 catalysts show high ID/IG ratios, which indicates that the graphitization degree of coke deposits generated by catalysts with larger Pt particles is low. With an increase in the transition metal Mn doping amount, the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 and Pt/20Mn-SBA-15 catalysts show smaller ID/IG ratios, which indicates that the graphitization degree of coke deposits generated by catalysts with better Pt dispersion is high, and the coke deposits generated by these catalysts are mainly graphitized carbon deposits. In order to further investigate the coke deposition on the catalyst, thermogravimetric analysis was conducted and the results are shown in Fig. 11. The amount of coke increases with an increase in the Mn doping amount. There are two types of weight loss, which represent two types of coke deposition. First, weight loss at low temperatures represents the formation of coke deposits on the Pt active site. Second, the coke precursor on the metal is transferred to the xMn-SBA-15 support, after which coke deposits are formed. Among the Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts, the coke deposited on metals or support is not obvious on the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst. Moreover, the weight loss is 2.5%, indicating that the amount of coke is low. This is related to the low activity of the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst. Compared with the Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, coke was mainly deposited on the support, not the metal, when using Pt/Mn-SBA-15 catalysts, indicating the addition Mn favorable coke migration from metal to support, similar to the effect of promoter Sn.[46] It shows that the addition of appropriate transition metal Mn species is beneficial to the transfer of coke deposits from active sites to the support, thus exposing more active sites and maintaining activity. 4 Conclusions The Mn-SBA-15 supports were prepared by in situ hydrothermal method under the condition of citric acid and urea. The addition of Mn in SBA-15 supports enhances the interaction of metal Pt and support, resulting in high Pt dispersion on Pt/Mn-SAB-15 catalysts. Moreover, the electron-donating property of Mn species increases the electron density on Pt, which is beneficial to the desorption of propylene product and can effectively inhibit the deep dehydrogenation, thus improving the PDH performance of the catalyst. Pt/xMn-SBA-15 catalysts doped with different contents of transition metal Mn species were applied to PDH, among which Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalyst showed the highest catalytic performance. After 6 h reaction, the propane conversion decreased from 51.2% to 49.3%, and the propylene selectivity remained above 97%. The reason is that an appropriate amount Mn doping can effectively stabilize the high dispersion Pt active sites by the strong metal-support interaction, thus enhancing PDH performance of the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The development of stable Pt-based catalysts is important for propane dehydrogenation process. In this work, Mn-SBA-15 supports with different Mn doping amounts were prepared by in situ hydrothermal method using citric acid and urea. Compared with Pt/SBA-15 catalyst, the significantly improved dispersion and stability of Pt on Pt/Mn-SBA-15 catalysts were demonstrated by X-ray diffraction and transmission electron microscopy results. CO DRIFT spectra analysis showed the electron transfer from Mn to Pt occurred, which led to an increase in the electron density of Pt. And the propane dehydrogenation performances over Pt/Mn-SBA-15 were enhanced significantly. Among them, the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 shows the highest initial propane conversion of 51.2% and lowest deactivation rate constant of 0.013 h−1. The reason may be that appropriate amount of Mn can modify Pt by both electronic effect and geometric effect. And the strong metal-support interaction formed by highly dispersed MnO x anchor sites in Mn-SBA-15 support maintains the stability of Pt during the propane dehydrogenation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Stable Pt catalysts anchored by Mn-SBA-15 support for propane dehydrogenation
